results.title: Bad Street Brawler for NES
results.material_description: Cartridge videogame. Cartridge, manual and blurb card in cardboard box
results.brief_description: In Bad Street Brawler, the player plays the character Duke Davis, a former punk rocker and the “world’s coolest” martial artist. Duke has to work his way through each level beating up the crooks that get in his way. Before the start of the next stage, quotes are introduced to entertain the player, such as “Never trouble trouble until trouble troubles you”. The player’s moves are limited to kicks and punches but new moves and attacks become available as the game progresses, along with new enemy types such as gorillas flinging bananas, menacing stakeboarders and circus strongmen. Bad Street Brawler is one of two games designed specifically for Mattel’s Power Glove.

results.title: Balls of Steel for PC
results.material_description: CD-ROM videogame. CD-ROM in CD jewel case with insert and manual
results.brief_description:
Balls of Steel is a top-down pinball computer game that features five fully-animated pinball tables, each with its own theme, missions, and special bonuses. One of the tables is themed on Duke Nukem, a franchise that Balls of Steel’s publisher, Apogee Software, developed. This tie-in continues to Duke Nukem series itself, where the pinball game appears in several releases.

Balls of Steel plays on a top-down scrolling screen, with an animated dot matrix display at the bottom mimicking the displays of actual pinball tables. As with its real-life counterpart, it shows the player score and animated graphics. Each table can also be viewed in its entirety. High scores are awarded with a “powerball” bonus mode, and could be posted on the “WorldScores” website for a global ranking, although this feature has since been discontinued.

results.title: Aussie Rules Footy for NES
results.material_description: Cartridge videogame. Cartridge, cartridge sleeve and manual in cardboard box
results.brief_description:
Aussie Rules Footy was Beam Software’s first Nintendo Entertainment System (NES) sports game developed exclusively for the Australian market. Despite simple controls, its clever design captured the high-energy, competitive spirit of the sport, featuring spectacular high marking and pushing other players out from under a mark.

It also contained Beam’s signature sense of humour. Though voice samples were unusual in NES games of the era, Aussie Rules Footy used voice lines like the deadpan umpire’s “out of bounds on the full”, which complemented the droll text-based commentary between quarters.

Despite the official AFL logo on the box, it’s unlikely the game was licensed, which could be why the 18 playable teams don’t match their real-life counterparts, with curious inclusions like Darwin, Canberra and Hobart.

results.title: [Brookes Family Home Movies: Reel 9]
results.brief_description:
This film shows a schoolboy game of cricket being played on the turf wicket in the grounds of the Glamorgan Preparatory School in Toorak, Victoria. Glamorgan is the Toorak campus of the Geelong Grammar School in Geelong Victoria. The boys wear Geelong Grammar school caps. Behind the cricket pitch we can see the rooftops and chimneys of the grand homes of Toorak. There is a colourfully painted wall behind the cricketers depicting a scene of Governor Phillip raising the flag at Sydney Cove in 1788. A hand painted didactic says:
“Governor Phillip brought the First Fleet to anchor at Botany Bay but raised the flag at Sydney Cove January 26th 1788. This was the first Australia Day.”

We see the Glamorgan Vs Visitors scoreboard, runs being made, catches being taken and 4s being scored.

The film then takes us to a suburban backyard to show a young baby on a rug. There is some lovely footage of the baby trying to crawl, wearing a handmade necklace made from wooden cotton reels. The baby shares the backyard with other children who play on climbing equipment and engage with the baby.

We see a toddler dressed in rompers standing inside a playpen. The toddler pushes the playpen along from the inside, walking out onto a verandah. There is some delightful footage of a baby crawling along a garden path and playing in a container of water.

The film shows children playing and swimming in an above ground backyard swimming pool. They have kickboards and rubber rings which could be bicycle tyres. They take turns somersaulting into the water from the edge of the pool. After finishing swimming, and wrapped in towels, the children eat drum-stick style ice creams.

This film shows good examples of family at-home recreation and play equipment, including climbing equipment and a swimming pool. There are also examples of suburban architecture, children’s and babies’ fashion, baby paraphernalia such as a playpen, school sports playing fields and turf cricket.

This film was originally made on 16mm.

Selected highlights list:
00:01:25:00 School cricket match with painted Australia Day/Governor Phillip scene behind
00:03:52:00 Glamorgan score board
00:05:21:00 School boys playing cricket, umpire (teacher) and painted wall behind
00:06:50:00 Baby with necklace of wooden cotton reels
00:09:08:00 Toddler inside playpen, walking out onto the verandah
00:09:28:00 Toddler crawls across the verandah
00:10:51:00 Toddler in rompers crawling along a garden path to play in container of water
00:14:01:00 Children playing in backyard pool

results.title: An American woman's adventure = Mao xian de Mei Guo Nu Ren
results.creator_credit: August First Film Studio, Jia Wang and Shishu Yu
results.brief_description:
In the Early 1930s, Helen Snow, Edgar Snow and other American friends, broke through all the blockades and became the first to tell the world about the Communist Party of China. They are the pioneers of seeking truth; they are the friends of the Chinese forever.
Based on the biography of American journalist Helen Snow, who journeyed into China during the pre-World War II era and uncovered the story of the Communist Party in China. The film opens with the murder of a Caucasian woman by a group of masked men; after the murder they realise that their victim was not the intended one. The narrative takes place in China, it is the early stages of the civil war; we are introduced to the Central Army (The Kuomintang) and the North West Army. A telegram arrives for Captain Ou Yang-Chuan, of the Central Army, notifying him of the arrival of American reporter Helen Snow, and instructing him to control her activities while she is in China. Snow is stopped at the train station by officials who inform her of the blacklisting of her husband, Edgar Snow; and due to association, she too is forbidden to enter the country. Captain Ou eventually takes care of the situation by permitting Snow to remain in the country for 24 hours. Placing Snow under strict watch, she is told to remain at a designated hotel. After several attempts she manages to sneak off without her guards, and she meets a former student of her husband who is involved with the Red Army (the North West Army). They devise a plan for Snow to leave the city and enter the restricted war zones. The rest of the narrative involves Snow’s execution of these plans, of the obstacles that come her way; unexpected allies are made and the mystery of the hooded men is eventually revealed.

Historical Background:
The world’s largest political party, the Communist Party of China (CPC or CCP) was founded in May 1921 in Shanghai, and came to rule all of mainland China in 1949 after defeating its rival the Kuomintang (KMT) in the Chinese Civil War. The Western world first got a clear view of the main base of the Communist Party of China through Edgar Snow’s Red Star Over China. Snow was also the first person to present Mao as the main leader, as he was previously seen as just a guerrilla leader. Snow’s book, along with Pearl Buck’s ‘The Good Earth’, was the most influential book on Western understanding and sympathy for China in the 1930s. Snow recounts the months that he spent with the Chinese Red Army in the summer and fall of 1936. When Snow wrote, there were no reliable reports of what was going on in the Communist-controlled areas. Snow’s status as an international journalist not previously identified with the communist movement gave his reports the stamp of authenticity. The glowing pictures of life in the communist areas contrasted with the gloom and corruption of the Nationalist government. Many Chinese learned about Mao and the communist movement from the almost immediate translations of Mao’s autobiography, and readers in North America and Europe, especially those with liberal views, were heartened to learn of a movement which they interpreted as being anti-Fascist and progressive. Snow reported clearly Mao’s new United Front policy as one which would leave violent class struggles behind. Although Snow made clear that Mao’s ultimate aim was control of China, many readers got the impression that the Chinese communists were “agrarian reformers”. Many critics refer to Snow’s accounts as “myths”, which presents a romanticized and partial view; in the West, it is often blamed for the rise of Mao’s communism.
Helen Foster Snow was an American journalist who reported from China in the 1930s on the developing revolution in China and the Korean independence movement. While, like her husband, Edgar Snow, she was never a member of the Chinese or American Communist Party, she was sympathetic to the revolutionaries in China, whom she compared favourably to the Nationalists under Chiang Kai-shek. In the late 1940s, critics grouped her with the China Hands as one of those responsible for the “loss of China”, one who went beyond sympathy to active support of Mao’s revolution.

Researcher’s Comments:
It is interesting that the film focuses on Helen Snow’s experiences in China instead of her husband’s. Snow is portrayed as a brave and unconventional character. The choice of representing the Snows’ heroism through a female figure can be linked to the ideological underpinnings of Communist China. For centuries before the early 1900s, women were greatly deprived of rights and were present mainly to serve men. Women served as slaves, concubines, and prostitutes. It was Mao who established some equality between the two genders; he believed that the enforcement of gender equality could make China a world power. Within his reign, he shifted the oppression of Chinese women from producing for the home to producing for the state. Husbands were not allowed to abuse their wives, have concubines, or use prostitutes. Marriages could no longer be arranged, wives with unbound feet were encouraged, and divorce was made easier to obtain. Both sexes were forced to wear the same gender neutral padded clothing. These changes initially gave females an increasing sense of self-confidence as they were encouraged to join the work force, become a communist official, and pursue educational opportunities. This indeed was in stark contrast to centuries of being less than second class citizens. Women willingly followed Mao in 1958 with his provision of day-care and soup kitchens to push the patriotic “iron woman” into longer work hours for the benefit of the nation. Again, this can be interpreted as the filmmaker’s attempt at glorifying Communism and its ideologies.
The narrative can be likened to classical Hollywood spy films and old espionage serials. At face value, the film is uncomplicated and easy to watch; although the characters and the dialogue seem a little outdated and camp.
(3 stars - Mary Chen; May 22, 2010)

results.title: anywhere and here
results.credit_line:
Ian Burns
mixed media installation
ACMI Collection
results.brief_description:
‘anywhere and here’ is a suite of five interconnected kinetic sculptures which generate their own real-time video. It specifically explores the road movie genre, summoning familiar visions of the empty landscape, the wide open road and the car-in-motion, to destabilise powerful cinematic clichés.

‘anywhere and here’ was commissioned by ACMI and was exhibited at ACMI as “Ian Burns: In the Telling” in 2012-13.

Burns adapts existing appliances and domestic items and gives them new functions within his sculptures. This work draws meaning from the contrast between the projected image and the machinery out of which it is made.

The five sculptures that make up this work are linked via a video control system constructed by Burns and designed to switch between each of the structures at random. The images that are produced by the sculptures are projected onto the wall for the audience to view. Each scene generates its own live soundtrack. Burns has hacked an electronic keyboard to plunk out a simple music track. The keyboard becomes an integral part of the sculpture.

A shot of the moon suspended over water is based around a glass top table. The resulting optic effect simulates water movement and sparkle. A strip of plywood simulates the sky at dusk, while the moon is created by the projection of light through a hole in the wood.

On one end of a folding table the effect of a smoking chimney is generated using a plastic salad bowl with a LED light inside shining through a slit cut in the backing of a picture frame. The view from the camera is across a roll of hobby store brick print paper.

On the other end of the folding table, to simulate a high zoom shot of a plane passing overhead, Burns rotates a party store plastic salad bowl while a LED light inside the bowl generates the cloud effect. A fan usually used as a cooling device for a computer, generates the sound of the jet and shakes the camera to simulate the zoom effect on a hand-held camera.

A black vinyl chair has been stripped of all its vinyl until only a narrowing strip remains with slots cut out of it. The camera view of this under a red light gives it the look of a remote roadway in dry country.

The shot in close-up of a wheel with the white stripes of the road whizzing past is a road movie cliché. The sculpture is constructed out of an actual car wheel on a treadmill and a camera positioned to catch a cinematic view of the action.

The fifth sculpture comprises the central electronic system that guides the work as a whole.

results.title: [Kirsty Sword Gusmao Film Collection: Reel 3]
results.brief_description:
Titled The Stars Were. This film shows closeups of the children who starred in “Walking to School” and “The Bear”.

The film then moves on to show a tractor dragging flames to set fire to a dry paddock. We see various farm scenery including sheep, burning off, horse riding and a tractor ploughing a field.

The film then shows a narrative short story titled “The Wish Wizard” which could be an Eaglehawk Primary school production. This film shows school children discovering a book which contains a map to “The Olde Wishing Well”. They gather together and conjure up a wizard using a magic spell. We see good close ups of children’s faces as they interact with the wizard.

We then see a school boy walking and running down a country road where he discovers animal tracks in the dirt and encounters a woman wearing a red coat carrying apples in a basket.

This film shows good examples of school fashion, children’s faces and farming practices.

Selected highlights (timecodes from Access Overscan)
00:00:49:00 - Title card Story ‘The Bear’
00:01:05:00 - Burning off with tractor
00:02:56:00 - Title card ‘the wish wizard’

results.title: [Kirsty Sword Gusmao Film Collection: Reel 1]
results.brief_description:
This film shows a slice of life from a working dairy farm in central Gippsland, Victoria.

We see cows being milked, the milk cans being loaded onto trucks and in to the trays of utility cars. The milk is transported by road to the Maffra Co-operative Milk Products Company.

There are scenes of hay bales being driven around the paddocks in the back of a ute. The hay is divided in to sections and fed to the cattle. We see de-horned Jersey and Friesian cows and bulls eating the hay and children riding a WX 572 tractor.

There is footage of a newly born calf being licked clean by its mother and we see the calf’s first attempt to stand and take its first steps.

The film also shows a family visit to the Glenmaggie Dam Enlargement Project Observation Point.

Selected sequence list (timecodes from Access Overscan)
00:00:54:00 The Maffra Co-operative Milk Products Co LTD sign
00:02:12:00 Title card ‘A Calf is Born’
00:03:55:00 Dad and kids riding a tractor
00:04:00:00 Title card ‘Wattle Time’
00:04:38:00 Glenmaggie Dam Enlargement Project Observation Point

results.title: A Visit to Australia's Great Barrier Reef
results.brief_description:
This film tours of the waters around the Great Barrier Reef showing corals, fish, turtles and other features of the Reef. A highlight of the footage is of local Indigenous people sharing their skills.

Selected highlights list:

00:00:05:00 title card ‘A visit to Australia’s Great Barrier Reef’.

00:13:00:00 further title cards ‘Photographed by Mr Tom C. Marshall’ and ‘Photographed on Kodakchrome Film’. Presumably Kenneth is not behind the camera on this reel as some of it is under water.

00:21:00:00 ‘Part I’ title card introduces footage of family members in shallow reef waters examining corals, at one point with a hand held viewer of some sort.

00:01:43:00 stripey fish appear.

00:03:04:00 parrot fish being examined in and out of the water with a close up of one being held up close, almost speaking to the camera.

00:03:54:00 clown fish and flathead swimming among the coral.

00:04:16:00 title card ‘Part II’ appears followed by a close up of a giant clam and various sea creatures crawling along the seabed floor.

00:05:03:00 footage of shell seekers and shell collections including giant species held up to the camera for close inspection.

00:06:40:00 very large colourful sea urchin held close to camera followed by a long legged starfish and several sea snakes or eels.

00:08:35:00 large sea slug and creatures on seabed floor camouflaged among corals.

00:09:30:00 turtle and baby turtles entering the sea; octopus shots.

00:11:04:00 (possibly) Shearwater sea birds (Mutton Birds) nesting in low lying trees; egg in nest held to camera.

00:12:00:00 waterbirds and seagulls; looking for birds and eggs.

00:13:03:00 title card ‘Part IV’ footage of an island, showing groups of Indigenous school children and young people.

00:14:03:00 local Indigenous person showing us how to climb a coconut palm, harvest and drop the nuts as well as skilfully stripping away the husks with their teeth before enjoying the juice; palm fronds are then harvested from the trees with machetes.

00:16:09:00 weaving baskets from the split fronds.
